#Text=Also known as : Silver Hoard of Everbeek , & Zilverschat van Everbeek The third-century Roman silver hoard from Everbeek is one of the most high-profile archaeological finds of recent years in Flanders and it has contributed to the political debate surrounding amateur metal detection .
#Text=Its high profile is due not only to its scientific and financial value , but also to the circumstances of its discovery and curation .

#Text=Despite apparently being the result of illegal excavation by a metal-detector user , and remaining unreported for at least two years , it was acquired by the Provincial Archaeological Museum at Velzeke .
#Text=Discovery In December 2010 , the Provincial Archaeological Museum in Velzeke announced that it had acquired a Roman hoard of silver artefacts – a unique find in Belgium .

#Text=Ten silver objects , including four spoons and an ingot , and a golden hair pin had been found together inside a silver bowl decorated with floral and mythological motifs , which itself had been placed upside down inside a ceramic vessel .
#Text=The assemblage was dated to the second half of the third century AD .
#Text=The objects were reportedly found in 2008 in a field near the village of Everbeek .

#Text=The museum ’ s press release reporting the acquisition was picked up by most national newspapers , and due to the exceptional nature of the find and the circumstances surrounding its discovery it became the centre of a widely-publicised controversy , which was instrumental in putting metal detecting on the political agenda .
#Text=The find and its acquisition by the Museum of Velzeke sparked a controversy in Flemish archaeology for several reasons .
#Text=First , the details of the discovery were not disclosed for at least two years .
#Text=According to Flemish legislation , incidental finds that may ‘ reasonably be assumed ’ to have archaeological value must be reported to the authorities within three days of their discovery .
#Text=The finder had first offered the hoard to the Provincial Gallo-Roman Museum in Tongeren in 2008 .
#Text=The latter in turn referred the finder to the museum in Velzeke , which was also notified directly .

#Text=All parties involved had evidently been aware of the archaeological importance of the find for quite some time , but a formal report was only filed on 21 December 2010 following an express request by the Flanders Heritage Agency , which was alerted by the Museum ’ s press announcement .
#Text=As a result , the opportunity to follow up on the hoard find with further archaeological fieldwork had long passed .
#Text=A second cause of controversy was the unclear circumstances surrounding the hoard ’ s discovery .

#Text=Despite the finder ’ s initial declaration that he had come across the artefacts by chance , there were strong suspicions to the contrary from the start , which occasioned a parliamentary question a few weeks after the museum ’ s original announcement .
#Text=Only much later was it confirmed that the find had indeed been the result of systematic metal detection .
#Text=In addition , the finder admitted that he had continued digging after the initial discovery .
#Text=Any archaeological excavation in Flanders requires a government-issued permit , for which only qualified and experienced archaeologists are eligible .
#Text=Unauthorized archaeological metal detection by amateurs is explicitly prohibited .
#Text=Thus , if the facts as related in the publications referenced here are true , then it would appear to have been an illegal excavation .
#Text=In the ensuing political debate about amateur metal detecting , which also featured in the press , the Minister responsible for archaeological heritage acknowledged this fact .
#Text=However , he also stated that no procès-verbal had been drawn up due to the vague nature of the available information and the lack of evidence for the use of a metal detector .

#Text=Finally , the museum was criticized for its decision to acquire objects of illegal provenance , even though its stated intention was to prevent the hoard from disappearing into a private collection .
#Text=The museum paid ‘ a reasonable price ’ of €3000 , 10 per cent of the estimated value , to both landowner and finder .
#Text=This arrangement , though certainly testament to the integrity of the finder , is problematic because it implies that the find was accidental .
#Text=In fact this was not the case , and therefore , from a legal viewpoint , only the landowner was entitled to payment .

#Text=Following another , similar case of an exceptional archaeological find in which the use of a metal detector was suspected , the Flanders Heritage Agency ’ s alleged policy of tolerance towards amateur metal detection was questioned in a Parliamentary Commission on heritage .

#Text=The minister denied the formal existence of such a policy , but pointed out that active prosecution of metal detectorists reporting finds would be a counterproductive measure , resulting not in less metal detection but in fewer reported finds .

#Text=Partly as a result of this case , the recent draft of a new heritage decree would lift the ban on archaeological metal detecting by amateurs , instead envisioning the creation of a licensing system for amateur metal-detector users .
